Share.d:
Auto display brightness (project).
Is Android's Adaptive Screen Brightness driving you crazy?
Here is a simple replacement system that runs in Tasker.
It automatically sets display brightness based on ambient light ad auto-updates it every few seconds.
It includes a simple slider to manually tweak the auto settings to be a bit brighter or darker.
Can be installed as a Quick Settings Tile (just click the easy auto-install button).
Normally the project is run via the Quick Settings Tile and/or a Tasker Widget on the home screen set to run task "Display Brightness Slider".
You can also set up homescreen Tasker widgets to run tasks "Display Brightness Low", "Display Brightness Medium", and "Display Brightness High" for quick access to those settings.
Additionally you can shake your device to auto-run Display Brightness Medium - useful in situations where the light level has changed and you can't read the screen.
The project uses little or no noticeable amount of battery.
The project will display notifications every time it changes the brightness level. This is useful when first calibrating the app but quickly becomes annoying. Simply disable the notifications as soon as you no longer need them.
Version 1.09

Action.label: Loop
Only needed if variable read from text file
Init if not set or re-init if manual hit
Smoothed light curve, running average
Here are the various methods to set brightness based on ambient light readings
Log(log)
Sqrt (sqrt(x))
Sqrt (sqrt(x)) refined
Straight linear
Anything large than 20000 is full sunlight, so let's don't fool around
Due to the averaging in the previous step we will never get brightness to 1 unless we do something here
Due to the averaging in the previous step we will never get brightness to 1 unless we do something here
Little smoothing
Loop to gradually change brightness if large changes are needed
Loop
Loop
Because of the time smoothing / moving average of light level, to get to a certain level we need to call the routine about 5-6 times
Loop

Share.d: Moves the location quick setting tile to the first position.

Action.label: Create Tasker quick tile (2nd, index 1) and Insert the new Tasker quick setting at the first of the list of quick settings
You can set this to whatever your app name is, if using app factory
custom(net.dinglisch.android.taskerm/.QSTileService1) (0,1,2)
net.dinglisch.* if running in Tasker, or the package ID if self standing app

Action.Str:
Set Up Quick Settings Tile to Open Display Brightness

The Display Brightness Quick Settings Tile has been created and enabled. It is listed with your other Quick Settings Tiles. To use it, you will need to manually add the Display Brightness Tile to your active Quick Settings Tiles. Step by step instructions to do that:

1. Edit Quick Settings Tiles (in Android 9, pull the settings shade down 2X, then click the little pencil)

2. Scroll down to find the Display Brightness Tile

3. Drag it up to the position you want

4. Save the Quick Settings Tiles

5. Now you can just touch the quick settings tile whenever you need to adjust your screen brightness
